questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of loss of urine for the last several months. She loses small amounts of urine without warning after coughing or sneezing. She also sometimes forgets the names of her relatives. She is retired and lives at an assisted-living facility. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her older sister recently received a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include metformin and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. She walks without any problems. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Bacterial infection of the urinary tract

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Detrusor overactivity is an important cause of urge incontinence. This form of urinary incontinence is characterized by a strong, sudden urge to urinate, which results in involuntary leakage of urine. However, this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is not preceded by any urge to urinate.

B) INCORRECT:

Complete loss of sphincter function would cause total urinary incontinence, which is characterized by continuous urinary leakage with no associated preceding symptoms or specific trigger activity. Complete loss of sphincter function is unlikely in this patient, who exhibits urinary expulsion preceded by physical stress.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired detrusor contractility is the underlying mechanism of overflow incontinence, which is characterized by frequent, involuntary dribbling of urine that occurs when the bladder is full. Since this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress rather than a feeling of bladder fullness, this is unlikely to be the underlying cause here.

D) CORRECT:

Urethral hypermobility is one of the most common causes of stress incontinence and is caused by impaired support from the pelvic floor. At times of increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, coughing, sneezing), the proximal urethra and the bladder neck descend out of the pelvis and transmit more pressure to the bladder. During this process, intraurethral pressure falls below bladder pressure, resulting in urine leakage. Considering this patient's age and gender, urethral hypermobility can result from postmenopausal estrogen loss and as part of the normal aging process.

Treatment of stress incontinence includes lifestyle modifications, Kegel exercises, and insertion of a vaginal pessary. If conservative treatment is insufficient, pharmacological and surgical treatment can be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia is the underlying mechanism of reflex incontinence, which is characterized by unpredictable urinary leakage that occurs when the bladder is full or otherwise stimulated (e.g., by cold air). This occurs due to simultaneous dyssynergistic contractions of the sphincter and the detrusor muscle, brought about by an underlying neurologic condition like multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injury. This patient has no such condition and exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress.

F) INCORRECT:

A urinary tract infection could possibly cause incontinence. Preexisting diabetes mellitus, in the setting of forgetfulness (and thus, possibly poor personal hygiene), could increase the chance of infection in this patient. However, the lack of typical features of infection, like fever and dysuria, make this a highly unlikely underlying cause of this patient's condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Decreased cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) absorption is the underlying pathology in normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). This condition often manifests in adults > 60 years of age and commonly manifests with signs of dementia and urinary incontinence, which are both seen in this elderly patient. However, the absence of gait disturbance, which is typically the initial and most prominent symptom of the disease, makes this diagnosis unlikely. Also, the incontinence in NPH is usually of the urge type, in which the patient experiences a strong, sudden urge to urinate, followed by urinary leakage. Since this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is not preceded by any urge to urinate, decreased CSF absorption is unlikely to be the underlying cause.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).
questions.hint: This patient presents with loss of urine with physical stress such as coughing, sneezing, and laughing. These features suggest a diagnosis of stress incontinence.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of loss of urinary control for the last year. The patient states that she loses control over her bladder when walking or standing up. She reports frequent, small-volume urine losses with no urge to urinate prior to the leakage. She tried to strengthen her pelvic muscles with supervised Kegel exercises and using a continence pessary but her symptoms did not improve. The patient is sexually active with her husband. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her hemoglobin A1c is 6.3% and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 100 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical vaginal estrogen is indicated in patients with vaginal atrophy, a common condition in postmenopausal women that may also manifest with symptoms of urinary incontinence. However, she is lacking typical signs of atrophy such as vaginal dryness, irritation, and dyspareunia.

B) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine is only used off-label for urinary stress incontinence; it is not yet approved in the US for this indication. Duloxetine is thought to enhance sphincter contraction as a result of inhibiting serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake at the spinal level.

C) INCORRECT:

Urethropexy (colposuspension) used to be the gold standard surgical procedure following unsuccessful conservative management of stress incontinence. However, it requires laparotomy or laparoscopy and is associated with a long operative duration and increased risk of certain postoperative complications (e.g., urgency incontinence). Urethropexy may be preferred in a patient who also requires repair of pelvic organ prolapse.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucosuria in poorly controlled diabetes mellitus may cause polyuria as glucose causes osmotic movement of water into the tubules. Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections that may cause unintentional voiding due to dysuria, frequency, and urgency. However, this patient's diabetes is well controlled and her loss of urine with light physical stress suggests stress incontinence.

E) INCORRECT:

Biofeedback is a supplemental modality for those learning pelvic floor muscle strengthening exercises with difficulty identifying the proper muscles. Sensors placed close to the anus are connected to a computer screen, displaying a graph with the patient's muscle contractions. While biofeedback may be helpful in regaining bladder control in urinary incontinence, this woman has already tried supervised muscle strengthening exercises, which did not relieve her symptoms.

F) CORRECT:

A urethral sling is the first-line surgical procedure for stress incontinence if conservative therapy, consisting of pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises), lifestyle changes (e.g., weight loss, alcohol cessation), and use of continence pessaries have failed. The sling is inserted via vaginal approach and supports and partially compresses the urethral lumen, thereby decreasing or stopping urinary leakage when intraabdominal pressure increases. Complications following the procedure include erosion of sling material with formation of fistulas, urinary obstruction (if the sling is too tense), damage to the bladder and bowel, pain, bleeding, and urinary tract infections.
questions.hint: This patient presents with loss of urine with light physical stress (walking and standing up), features which suggest moderate stress incontinence.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman reports a 6-month history of daily urinary incontinence that occurs after coughing, sneezing, and laughing. She does not report any urinary urgency, increased urinary frequency, changes in the color or smell of the urine, or fecal incontinence.
She has had three pregnancies, each with a vaginal delivery, and her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. Her BMI is 22. Abdominal and pelvic examinations are normal.
Urinalysis shows no evidence of a urinary tract infection. The residual urinary volume after voiding is within the normal range.
What is the most appropriate initial treatment of this patient’s urinary incontinence?

choices.text: Initiation of hormone-replacement therapy with a combination of estrogen and progesterone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hormone-replacement therapy has been associated with an increased incidence of stress urinary incontinence and is thus not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Stress urinary incontinence refers to involuntary leakage of urine that happens with increased abdominal pressure (as occurs during coughing, laughing, and sneezing), leading to increased bladder pressure that exceeds urethral resistance. Risk factors include middle age (peak incidence at 45–49 years), multiple pregnancies with vaginal delivery, and obesity.

After urinary tract infection and urinary retention (overflow incontinence) are ruled out, first-line treatment consists of pelvic-floor muscle training (commonly known as Kegel exercises) and incontinence pessaries. Pelvic-floor exercises (30–50 contractions of the pelvic-floor muscles each day) are often the preferred initial strategy for patients interested in pursuing therapy that is less invasive than surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for stress urinary incontinence in women is a regimen of pelvic-floor exercises.

C) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine hydrochloride is not approved for stress urinary incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

Urethral bulking agents are a surgical treatment option for stress urinary incontinence, but they are not the first-line treatment option.

E) INCORRECT:

Tolterodine is used to treat urge incontinence.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man who underwent a radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer 2 months ago reports persistent urinary incontinence that occurs when he coughs, sneezes, or lifts weights. He has not noticed dysuria, hematuria, or changes in the color or odor of his urine.
The patient’s medical history includes hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a prior myocardial infarction. His current medications — atenolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin — have been stable for the past 4 years.
His vital signs and physical examination are normal. His BMI is 23.5. Urinalysis is unremarkable, and postvoid residual volume is normal.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Strengthening exercises for the pelvic muscles

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antimuscarinic agents, such as tolterodine and oxybutynin, can be used if symptoms are compatible with urge incontinence and overactive bladder, because these agents reduce involuntary bladder contractions. Typical symptoms of urge incontinence and overactive bladder include a sudden urge to void and voiding triggered by sensations such as hearing water run and touching or drinking water. Unfortunately, antimuscarinic agents are poorly tolerated because of their anticholinergic side effects, including dry mouth, constipation, and drowsiness.

B) INCORRECT:

Intermittent self-catheterization is indicated if the patient has an atonic bladder with high residual volumes that lead to urinary retention and recurrent infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of an alpha-blocker, such as terazosin, is helpful if there is a component of bladder outlet obstruction, because these agents help relax the smooth muscle of the bladder neck. Although data on the use of alpha-blockade after radical prostatectomy is lacking, initiation will not help improve symptoms of stress incontinence and may worsen them.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that most patients who have urinary incontinence after radical prostatectomy improve and that conservative therapy helps most patients, a conservative therapy strategy is recommended for 6 to 12 months before trying invasive procedures, such as surgical creation of a urethral sling.

E) CORRECT:

Stress incontinence occurs in up to 40% of patients after radical prostatectomy and often reduces quality of life. Conservative therapy includes weight loss (in the setting of obesity) and strengthening exercises of the pelvic muscles. In addition, lifestyle changes, such as limiting fluid intake and avoiding known bladder irritants, can be helpful.

Given that most patients who have urinary incontinence after radical prostatectomy improve and that conservative therapy helps most patients, a conservative therapy strategy is recommended for 6 to 12 months before trying invasive procedures, such as surgical creation of a urethral sling.

Key learning point: For bothersome urinary incontinence within the first year after radical prostatectomy, the recommended management approach is conservative therapy, including strengthening exercises for the pelvic muscles and weight loss in the setting of obesity.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman reports a one-year history of progressive urinary incontinence that occurs during coughing, sneezing, and laughing. It has had a noticeable effect on her quality of life during the past 2 months.
She has been postmenopausal for the past 10 years. Her medical history includes only a traumatic arm fracture and four full-term vaginal deliveries. She does not use tobacco, she drinks alcohol socially, and she exercises regularly. A physical examination is unremarkable, although there is thinning, pallor, and loss of rugae in the vaginal wall.
Which one of the following tests is the most appropriate initial evaluation for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of the urinary flow rate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although low estrogen levels may contribute indirectly to the development of postmenopausal urinary incontinence, measuring estrogen levels has no diagnostic value in the evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Scanning of the bladder, including the postvoid residual urinary volume, has limited diagnostic value in the initial evaluation and is not recommended for the routine evaluation of women with symptoms of incontinence. Such scanning is necessary before invasive anti-incontinence surgery or if there is a question of overflow incontinence caused by bladder-outlet obstruction, which is unlikely in a woman.

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring peak urine flow (the urinary flow rate) is not recommended in women.

D) CORRECT:

Urinary incontinence is a common condition, affecting millions of women. The majority of presentations can be characterized as stress, urge, or mixed-type urinary incontinence. Stress urinary incontinence manifests as leakage of urine in the presence of increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during coughing or laughing. It is most commonly caused by a weak pelvic floor, often after several vaginal deliveries.

The first and easiest test in evaluating urinary incontinence is urinalysis, to rule out a urinary tract infection. Although asymptomatic bacteriuria does not cause urinary incontinence, increasing incontinence may be the only presenting symptom of a urinary tract infection.

Key learning point: In a woman with urinary leakage and other symptoms of stress urinary incontinence, the initial diagnostic test should be urinalysis, to rule out a urinary tract infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Routine urodynamic testing is not recommended to evaluate urinary incontinence. Urodynamic studies are invasive and expensive, require special equipment and training, are not usually necessary to make a diagnosis, and have not been found to affect outcomes in this situation. Urodynamic studies are helpful in the workup of neurogenic bladder.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman with a history of four vaginal deliveries reports a 20-year history of urine leakage, which has become more bothersome to her during the past 6 months. She reports no dysuria, hematuria, urinary frequency, or fecal incontinence. Her medical history includes nephrolithiasis, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. Her current medications include chlorthalidone, extended-release nifedipine, atorvastatin, aspirin, and metformin. She also started insulin 9 months ago and has gained 11 kg since then.
Her current weight is 82.3 kg, and her BMI is 34. She has a blood pressure of 136/84 mm Hg and a heart rate of 78 beats per minute. On physical examination, she has stage III uterine prolapse during a Valsalva maneuver. She can produce only a weak voluntary contraction of the pelvic floor muscles when instructed to do so. Sensation is intact over the perineum, and neurologic examination of the lower extremities is within normal limits.
Which one of the following historical details is this patient most likely to report?

choices.text: Sensation of incomplete bladder emptying after voiding
Inability to get to the toilet on time when sensing the urge to void

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections can cause urinary incontinence, but it is typically urge incontinence rather than stress incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Nocturia is considered a normal circumstance once per night.

C) CORRECT:

Determining the type of urinary incontinence in a female patient is important for recommending a management plan, and the patient’s history provides key information.

Stress incontinence occurs when bladder pressure exceeds urethral resistance in the setting of increased abdominal pressure. It is characterized by involuntary urine leakage during coughing, sneezing, lifting, or exercising. Incidence is highest during middle age (40–49). Risk factors include obesity, multiple pregnancies with vaginal delivery, and non-Hispanic white race. Pelvic examination often reveals prolapse of pelvic organs. Asking the patient to contract the pelvic muscles against the examiner’s finger and assessing the strength of the contraction can aid in diagnosing stress incontinence. The “cough stress test” is also useful; it is performed by asking the patient to cough with a full bladder and observing the urethra for urine leakage.

First-line treatment for mild stress incontinence is pelvic-floor therapy (30–50 contractions of the pelvic-floor muscles each day, commonly known as Kegel exercises) or pelvic-floor biofeedback training. Second-line therapy can include pelvic-floor reconstruction or urethral sling procedures and requires referral to urology or urogynecology.

Key learning point: Involuntary urine leakage during coughing, sneezing, lifting, or exercising is a typical manifestation of stress incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

The sensation of incomplete bladder emptying suggests urinary retention, which can result in overflow incontinence.

E) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence occurs when overactive detrusor-muscle contractions exceed urethral resistance. Patients typically report an inability to get to the toilet on time when sensing the urge to void, which is not a historical feature of stress incontinence.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman reports a 6-month history of daily urinary incontinence that occurs after coughing, sneezing, and laughing. She does not report any urinary urgency, increased urinary frequency, changes in the color or smell of the urine, or fecal incontinence. Risk factors include middle age (peak incidence at 45–49 years), multiple pregnancies with vaginal delivery, and obesity. After urinary tract infection and urinary retention (overflow incontinence) are ruled out, first-line treatment consists of pelvic-floor muscle training (commonly known as Kegel exercises) and incontinence pessaries. Pelvic-floor exercises (30–50 contractions of the pelvic-floor muscles each day) are often the preferred initial strategy for patients interested in pursuing therapy that is less invasive than surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for stress urinary incontinence in women is a regimen of pelvic-floor exercises.

C) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine hydrochloride is not approved for stress urinary incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

Urethral bulking agents are a surgical treatment option for stress urinary incontinence, but they are not the first-line treatment option.

E) INCORRECT:

Tolterodine is used to treat urge incontinence.

She reports no dysuria, hematuria, urinary frequency, or fecal incontinence. On physical examination, she has stage III uterine prolapse during a Valsalva maneuver. She can produce only a weak voluntary contraction of the pelvic floor muscles when instructed to do so. Sensation is intact over the perineum, and neurologic examination of the lower extremities is within normal limits. Which one of the following historical details is this patient most likely to report?

choices.text: Sensation of incomplete bladder emptying after voiding
Inability to get to the toilet on time when sensing the urge to void

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections can cause urinary incontinence, but it is typically urge incontinence rather than stress incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Nocturia is considered a normal circumstance once per night.

C) CORRECT:

Determining the type of urinary incontinence in a female patient is important for recommending a management plan, and the patient’s history provides key information. Stress incontinence occurs when bladder pressure exceeds urethral resistance in the setting of increased abdominal pressure. It is characterized by involuntary urine leakage during coughing, sneezing, lifting, or exercising. Incidence is highest during middle age (40–49). Risk factors include obesity, multiple pregnancies with vaginal delivery, and non-Hispanic white race. The “cough stress test” is also useful; it is performed by asking the patient to cough with a full bladder and observing the urethra for urine leakage. First-line treatment for mild stress incontinence is pelvic-floor therapy or pelvic-floor biofeedback training.

Key learning point: Involuntary urine leakage during coughing, sneezing, lifting, or exercising is a typical manifestation of stress incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

The sensation of incomplete bladder emptying suggests urinary retention, which can result in overflow incontinence.

E) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence occurs when overactive detrusor-muscle contractions exceed urethral resistance. Patients typically report an inability to get to the toilet on time when sensing the urge to void, which is not a historical feature of stress incontinence.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents with a 5-month history of involuntary urine leakage. She first noticed it after a sneezing episode and now experiences leakage when laughing or lifting heavy items. She denies urgency or burning with urination. She has had two vaginal deliveries and has no significant medical history. Physical examination reveals a mild cystocele on Valsalva maneuver. Neurological examination is normal.
Which diagnosis best explains her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence is characterized by bladder overdistension, incomplete emptying, and a weak urinary stream, often due to detrusor underactivity or obstruction. The patient's symptoms of leakage during increased intra-abdominal pressure and normal neurological examination do not align with overflow incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence involves a sudden, intense need to urinate, often with increased frequency and urgency. It is typically due to detrusor muscle overactivity. The absence of urgency or burning with urination and the presence of a cystocele suggest a structural issue rather than detrusor overactivity.

C) CORRECT:

Stress incontinence manifests with involuntary urine leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, or laughing. This condition results from weakened pelvic floor structures, often due to factors like multiple vaginal deliveries. The weakened support impairs the urethral closure mechanism, leading to leakage. The presence of a mild cystocele on Valsalva maneuver indicates compromised pelvic support, further supporting the diagnosis of stress incontinence. This condition is distinct from other types of incontinence, as it lacks symptoms of urgency or frequency.

Key learning point: Stress incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, or laughing, and is commonly associated with childbirth.

D) INCORRECT:

Functional incontinence occurs when cognitive or physical impairments prevent timely bathroom access, despite normal urinary tract function. The patient's leakage during activities like sneezing and laughing, along with normal neurological findings, suggests a mechanical issue rather than functional impairment.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with involuntary leakage of urine whenever she coughs, sneezes, or lifts heavy objects. She is five months postpartum after a vaginal delivery complicated by a second-degree perineal tear. She denies any recurring urge to urinate or difficulty initiating micturition. Physical examination reveals descent of the bladder neck during Valsalva maneuver, but no neurological deficits or signs of infection.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence results from impaired detrusor contractility or obstruction, leading to bladder overdistension and continuous dribbling. It often presents with difficulty initiating micturition and a sensation of incomplete voiding, which are not present. The leakage during increased intra-abdominal pressure and bladder neck descent indicates stress urinary incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Urge urinary incontinence is characterized by a sudden, compelling need to void, often due to detrusor overactivity. It typically presents with urgency, frequency, and nocturia, which are absent here. The leakage associated with increased intra-abdominal pressure and bladder neck descent suggests stress urinary incontinence, not urge incontinence.

C) CORRECT:

Stress urinary incontinence manifests with involuntary urine leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, or lifting. In postpartum women, this condition often results from pelvic floor dysfunction due to vaginal delivery, especially with perineal injury. The weakened pelvic support structures and urethral sphincter mechanism lead to bladder neck descent during Valsalva maneuver. This descent indicates pelvic floor laxity, a hallmark of stress urinary incontinence. The absence of urgency or difficulty initiating micturition further supports this diagnosis.

Key learning point: Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, or laughing, and is often associated with pelvic floor weakness after childbirth.

D) INCORRECT:

Functional incontinence occurs due to external factors like mobility or cognitive impairments, not lower urinary tract abnormalities. It is unlikely in a young, postpartum woman without physical or cognitive limitations. The leakage during increased intra-abdominal pressure and bladder neck descent points to stress urinary incontinence.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old overweight mother of two presents with accidental urine leakage, mostly when coughing, sneezing, or during exercise. Her symptoms began after the birth of her second child. She reports no urinary urgency, increased frequency, or nocturia. She denies difficulty initiating urination or a weak stream. Physical examination shows mild pelvic floor laxity.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence is due to detrusor overactivity and presents with sudden urgency, increased frequency, and nocturia. The absence of these symptoms and the presence of leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure suggest a different mechanism. The clinical details do not indicate bladder irritation or neurological triggers typical of urge incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Functional incontinence occurs due to physical or cognitive impairments preventing timely toilet access despite normal urinary function. The patient's leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure and the absence of cognitive or mobility issues suggest pelvic floor weakness, not functional limitations, as the cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence involves incomplete bladder emptying, leading to continuous dribbling, hesitancy, and weak stream. The patient's leakage during increased intra-abdominal pressure without voiding difficulties suggests a different cause. Conditions like diabetic neuropathy or bladder outlet obstruction, which lead to overflow incontinence, are not supported by the clinical information.

D) CORRECT:

Stress urinary incontinence manifests when increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during coughing, sneezing, or exercise, overcomes the resistance of the pelvic floor and urethral sphincter. This condition is common after childbirth due to weakened pelvic support structures. The patient's history of childbirth and pelvic floor laxity indicates compromised bladder support, leading to urine leakage during stress maneuvers. Chronic conditions like chronic obstructive pulmonary disease can exacerbate this by causing persistent coughing, further weakening pelvic support. The pathophysiology involves mechanical stress and weakened muscular support, resulting in urinary leakage during activities that elevate intra-abdominal pressure.

Key learning point: Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, and is often associated with obesity and weakened pelvic floor muscles.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old G3P3 woman presents with involuntary leakage of small amounts of urine when she exercises or sneezes for the last six months. She denies frequency, urgency, or dysuria. She has no other significant medical history. A standing cough test reproduces the leakage. Pelvic exam shows normal sensation and no masses. Post-void residual volume is 20 mL.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The midurethral sling procedure is a surgical treatment for stress urinary incontinence, typically considered after conservative measures have failed.

B) INCORRECT:

Antimuscarinic medications (e.g., oxybutynin) are used to treat urge incontinence by reducing involuntary detrusor contractions. This patient exhibits stress urinary incontinence, not urgency or frequency characteristic of urge incontinence, making antimuscarinics inappropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Stress urinary incontinence manifests as urine leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing or jogging, due to weakened pelvic support structures. Multiparity is a risk factor for stress incontinence. Conservative management of urinary incontinence is first-line therapy for most patients and includes lifestyle and behavioral modifications (e.g., smoking cessation), pelvic floor muscle exercises, and the use of a vaginal pessary. Pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises) strengthen the levator ani muscles, which support the bladder neck and urethra, reducing urine leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure. A vaginal pessary supports the urethra and increase resistance. Surgical management is only recommended if there is inadequate improvement with conservative management of urinary incontinence (see “Overview of urinary incontinence” table).

Key learning point: Pelvic floor muscle exercises are the first-line treatment for stress urinary incontinence, which is characterized by urine leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Intermittent self-catheterization is used for urinary retention or overflow incontinence, not stress incontinence. This patient with a normal post-void residual volume (< 100 mL) does not have impaired bladder emptying.

questions.text: You are seeing a 70-year-old woman in your clinic for evaluation of urinary incontinence that has been present for several months. She reports losing small amounts of urine without warning, particularly after coughing or sneezing. She also notes occasional difficulty recalling the names of her relatives. She is retired and lives in an assisted-living facility. Her medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her older sister recently received a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her medications are metformin and enalapril. Vital signs are normal. She ambulates without difficulty. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Complete loss of sphincter function would cause total urinary incontinence, which is characterized by continuous urinary leakage with no associated preceding symptoms or specific trigger activity. Complete loss of sphincter function is unlikely in this patient, who exhibits urinary expulsion preceded by physical stress.

B) CORRECT:

Urethral hypermobility is one of the most common causes of stress incontinence and is caused by impaired support from the pelvic floor. At times of increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, coughing, sneezing), the proximal urethra and the bladder neck descend out of the pelvis and transmit more pressure to the bladder. During this process, intraurethral pressure falls below bladder pressure, resulting in urine leakage. Considering this patient's age and gender, urethral hypermobility can result from postmenopausal estrogen loss and as part of the normal aging process.

Treatment of stress incontinence includes lifestyle modifications, Kegel exercises, and insertion of a vaginal pessary. If conservative treatment is insufficient, pharmacological and surgical treatment can be considered.

Key learning point: Stress urinary incontinence is most commonly caused by urethral hypermobility due to weakened pelvic floor support, leading to urine leakage with increased intraabdominal pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired detrusor contractility is the underlying mechanism of overflow incontinence, which is characterized by frequent, involuntary dribbling of urine that occurs when the bladder is full. Since this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress rather than a feeling of bladder fullness, this is unlikely to be the underlying cause here.

D) INCORRECT:

Detrusor overactivity is an important cause of urge incontinence. This form of urinary incontinence is characterized by a strong, sudden urge to urinate, which results in involuntary leakage of urine. However, this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is not preceded by any urge to urinate.

E) INCORRECT:

Detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia is the underlying mechanism of reflex incontinence, which is characterized by unpredictable urinary leakage that occurs when the bladder is full or otherwise stimulated (e.g., by cold air). This occurs due to simultaneous dyssynergistic contractions of the sphincter and the detrusor muscle, brought about by an underlying neurologic condition like multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injury. This patient has no such condition and exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress.
questions.hint: This patient presents with loss of urine with physical stress such as coughing, sneezing, and laughing. These features suggest a diagnosis of stress incontinence.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of daily urinary incontinence that occurs with coughing, sneezing, and laughing. She does not report urinary urgency, increased frequency, changes in urine color or odor, or fecal incontinence. She has had three pregnancies, each with a vaginal delivery. Her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. Her BMI is 22. Abdominal and pelvic examinations are normal. Urinalysis shows no evidence of urinary tract infection. Post-void residual urine volume is within the normal range. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for her urinary incontinence?

choices.text: Initiation of hormone-replacement therapy with a combination of estrogen and progesterone.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hormone-replacement therapy has been associated with an increased incidence of stress urinary incontinence and is thus not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Tolterodine is used to treat urge incontinence.

C) INCORRECT:

Urethral bulking agents are a surgical treatment option for stress urinary incontinence, but they are not the first-line treatment option.

D) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine hydrochloride is not approved for stress urinary incontinence.

E) CORRECT:

Stress urinary incontinence refers to involuntary leakage of urine that happens with increased abdominal pressure (as occurs during coughing, laughing, and sneezing), leading to increased bladder pressure that exceeds urethral resistance. Risk factors include middle age (peak incidence at 45–49 years), multiple pregnancies with vaginal delivery, and obesity. After urinary tract infection and urinary retention (overflow incontinence) are ruled out, first-line treatment consists of pelvic-floor muscle training (commonly known as Kegel exercises) and incontinence pessaries. Pelvic-floor exercises (30–50 contractions of the pelvic-floor muscles each day) are often the preferred initial strategy for patients interested in pursuing therapy that is less invasive than surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for stress urinary incontinence in women is a regimen of pelvic-floor exercises.

questions.text: You are seeing a 68-year-old woman with a history of four vaginal deliveries who reports a 20-year history of urine leakage that has become more bothersome over the past 6 months. She does not have dysuria, hematuria, urinary frequency, or fecal incontinence. On examination, she has stage III uterine prolapse during a Valsalva maneuver. She is able to produce only a weak voluntary contraction of the pelvic floor muscles when instructed. Sensation is intact over the perineum, and neurologic examination of the lower extremities is normal. Which one of the following historical details is this patient most likely to report?

choices.text: Inability to get to the toilet on time when sensing the urge to void.
Sensation of incomplete bladder emptying after voiding.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence occurs when overactive detrusor-muscle contractions exceed urethral resistance. Patients typically report an inability to get to the toilet on time when sensing the urge to void, which is not a historical feature of stress incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Nocturia is considered a normal circumstance once per night.

C) INCORRECT:

The sensation of incomplete bladder emptying suggests urinary retention, which can result in overflow incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections can cause urinary incontinence, but it is typically urge incontinence rather than stress incontinence.

E) CORRECT:

Determining the type of urinary incontinence in a female patient is important for recommending a management plan, and the patient’s history provides key information. Stress incontinence occurs when bladder pressure exceeds urethral resistance in the setting of increased abdominal pressure. It is characterized by involuntary urine leakage during coughing, sneezing, lifting, or exercising. Incidence is highest during middle age (40–49). Risk factors include obesity, multiple pregnancies with vaginal delivery, and non-Hispanic white race. The “cough stress test” is also useful; it is performed by asking the patient to cough with a full bladder and observing the urethra for urine leakage. First-line treatment for mild stress incontinence is pelvic-floor therapy or pelvic-floor biofeedback training.

Key learning point: Involuntary urine leakage during coughing, sneezing, lifting, or exercising is a typical manifestation of stress incontinence.

questions.text: A 72-year-old multiparous woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of episodes of involuntary urine leakage for the past 6 months. She loses small amounts of urine without warning after laughing or sneezing. She is retired and lives at an assisted-living facility. She has insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus type 2. Her mother received a ventriculoperitoneal shunt around her age. She walks without any problems. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Which of the following is the primary underlying etiology for this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia is the underlying mechanism of reflex incontinence, which is characterized by unpredictable urinary leakage that occurs when the bladder is full or otherwise stimulated (e.g., by cold air). This occurs due to simultaneous dyssynergistic contractions of the sphincter and the detrusor muscle, brought about by an underlying neurologic condition like multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injury. This patient has no such condition and exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress.

B) INCORRECT:

Detrusor overactivity is an important cause of urge incontinence. This form of urinary incontinence is characterized by a strong, sudden urge to urinate, which results in involuntary leakage of urine. However, this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is not preceded by an urge to urinate.

C) CORRECT:

Urethral hypermobility is one of the most common causes of stress incontinence and is caused by impaired support from the pelvic floor. At times of increased intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, coughing, sneezing), the proximal urethra and the bladder neck descend out of the pelvis and transit more pressure to the bladder. During this process, intraurethral pressure falls below bladder pressure, resulting in urine leakage. This patients age, previous childbirths, and postmenopausal estrogen loss are likely contributing factors to the development of a weakened pelvic floor and thus urethral hypermobility.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired detrusor contractility is the underlying mechanism of overflow incontinence, which is characterized by incomplete bladder emptying and frequent, involuntary dribbling of urine that occurs when the bladder is full. Since this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress rather than a feeling of bladder fullness, this is unlikely to be the underlying cause.

E) INCORRECT:

A complete loss of sphincter function would cause total incontinence, which is characterized by urinary leakage that continuously occurs without associated preceding symptoms or specific trigger activity. Loss of sphincter function is unlikely in this patient who exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress.
questions.hint: Urinary leakage upon activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure is suggestive of stress incontinence.
